Both themes run rampant in the show's five seasons, but the latest installment was more akin to Robert Frost’s poem Fire and Ice and had several characters choosing one or the other as a means of suicide or murder.
After a season of Arya washing away the death from the floors of the House of Black and White, and the dead bodies that pile up there, we finally see her confront the same topic in her life.
This struggle is best displayed by Stannis Baratheon who is advised by Melisandre to sacrifice his daughter Shireen for the Lord of Light, ensuring him victory as he marches on Winterfell.
While his love and dedication to Shireen was highlighted in stories about him hiring doctors to cure her Greyscale instead of banishing her, he doesn't care for her more than his dream.
Initially, Stannis opposed killing his kid, but succumbed to pressure after supplies were diminished in an overnight attack and snowfall continues to prevent an invasion.
The heartbreaking scene of Shireen's death was preceded by a sweet moment between her and Davos Seaworth, who was sent away by Stannis to go to The Wall for supplies.
We’ve also heard her declare revenge on those who have wronged her, crafting her list of people to kill that she recites instead of a lullaby to ease her into sleep.
As Jon gets the cold shoulder, Arya faces the devil – Meryn Trant, one of the men on her almost-forgotten murder list and a pedophile who enjoys raping young girls.
The Queen finally took the power in her dragons that she's been too coy to harness while Stannis cowardly used fire instead of bravery to get what he wants.
True to the book series' original name, A Song of Ice and Fire, the latest episode of Game of Thrones centered on hypothermic chills and charred flesh.
